text: What the blue pill beta marketing team at Gillette is doing is subversively implying that masculinity is the problem, body hair is masculine so it should be shaven (feminized) and men should be ashamed of themselves for imagined slights against women as a whole. Women are portrayed as helpless victims and this whole up is down shitshow results in a culture of feminist propaganda. The whole ad is hilarious and sad. #redpilltruth

@ali_khj the issue with the expectations of being feminine are that they’re often time consuming, expensive, not functional, and in most cases it’s a damned if we do, damned if we don’t. Ex- go on a date all dolled up for dinner, hair makeup etc. I had a guy say that I looked too high maintenance for him.  Another date I asked a guy to go to a shooting range with me. I put on makeup and he made fun of me. Another date went rock climbing so I was in gym clothes and no makeup. He said he liked girls that tried a little harder and said I’d be prettier with makeup and my hair curled. 🤷‍♀️ can’t win . And men aren’t required to do anything. I’ve requested that a man trim his beard up and I was called shallow. I requested that a man wear a nicer pearlsnap shirt because I was wearing a cute dress and cowgirl boots. And when we make the requests we’re typically told to F off. (Disclaimer this is more with younger boys under the age of 30. Older men I’ve found to typically dress nicer. And I’m not saying all boys either)

After reading most of the comments I have some things I’d like to say:

Firstly, you can’t say that the response of men towards this commercial is childish or ignorant. I can see both sides. If we, women, were portrayed in a similar manner in an ad there would we outrage for sure and it would be talked about in all the social media. The same should be expected in the case of men. On the other hand, I do understand what Gillette wanted to do (even though they poorly executed it). As someone else commented, they just wanted to bring awareness. Yes, not all men are rapists. Not all men are bullies. Not all men are as aggressive. But some men are. Otherwise domestic abuse in women wouldn’t be more than twice as high than in men. Rape of women wouldn’t be one in five, and in men just one in 71. Yes, women do falsely accuse people of rape. I don’t know how fucked up you have to be to do that but they do. However, the number of women who are too afraid to even talk about them being raped and come forward are far more. What I am trying to say is, that as a woman, I can see both sides. And I agree with what you men are trying to say. However, it isn’t okay to discriminate either gender. Women have had rough times and at times, sorry to say, harder then men. It is a fact. And if you’re not a woman you can’t possibly understand or have an absolute opinion on the matter - that would make you ignorant. But the same goes for us women, we cannot possibly understand what it is to be a man, and shouldn’t always try and bite some man’s head off when they are just simply trying to defend themselves. Not all men are bad, as not all women are bad. There are some wonderful men out there, and true heroes. That is my opinion anyways. And before people ‘attack’ me for it, it is just that, my opinion.

Not all men are blamed for the actions of bad men, it may feel that way, but if a man is good, he knows that he is good. And men as a whole will never be praised or blamed because men are not all the same. The overall point of the ad is that men need to stop the men that are bullying show them what is right. Treat people the way you want to be treated. I stand with Gillette.
